importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the incident was reported to the public and when the company responded publicly to the incident.
The date on which United Flight 1093 experienced the incident and initiated emergency landing.
The date on which WindBorne issued a public statement regarding the possible balloon impact.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The altitude range where WindBorne stated it has implemented changes to reduce balloon risk, indicating a critical flight altitude zone for such incidents.

keyTakeAways: A weather balloon from WindBorne may have struck the cockpit window of United Flight 1093, causing a crack and injuring a pilot.
The flight, a Boeing 737 from Denver to Los Angeles, safely landed in Salt Lake City after declaring an emergency due to the incident.

WindBorne, a California-based weather technology startup, acknowledged the possible involvement of its balloons and has taken immediate action to improve safety, including adjusting flight operations and developing autonomous collision avoidance systems.
The first officer sustained minor injuries and was treated upon landing, while all passengers and crew remained safe.
WindBorne is cooperating with the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) and the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) on the investigation.
The aircraft later flew to Rockford, Illinois, for maintenance, indicating the incident had significant operational impact on flight scheduling and aircraft logistics.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A United Airlines Boeing 737 flight (Flight 1093) traveling from Denver to Los Angeles experienced a cockpit window crack that injured a pilot, prompting an emergency landing in Salt Lake City. The company identified a weather balloon from startup WindBorne as a likely cause. WindBorne has responded by implementing operational changes to reduce exposure during key altitudes (30,000–40,000 feet), accelerating development of autonomous flight avoidance systems, and improving balloon design to reduce impact force. The incident has prompted cooperation between WindBorne and the NTSB and FAA, with all passengers and crew unharmed. The aircraft later flew to Rockford, Illinois, for maintenance, underscoring the broader implications for aviation safety and technology integration.
title: United flight’s cockpit window may have been struck by weather balloon, company says
